Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 01:37AM abcd wrote: It's an awful mistake, no one can tell us, it's all upto God or nature.  For us. on this forum, it's like a notice we all got but we all know that no one in this world is immortal.  We may live today but who knows what tomorrow holds for us?  Difficult to distract from this thought I know but enjoy the time with your loved one ( I am trying to do the same).   I wish peace of your mind and peace to us all.
Posts.Title: Seems as if time is running out... pee vision2020

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 12:29PM abcd wrote: Hi,  I am starting with FEC-T chemo from 12th of January 2011.   Seen my oncologist today, discussed in details.   I chose to have chemo first and if it works ( if the tumour shrinks), then lumpectomy with axillary node clearance, followed by radiation.  Initially starting with 18 weeks chemo.  I have appt prior to this on 7th Jan for PICC line.  This cannula will remain in my arm for 6 months!   Is it same with you all?   Hope to hear from someone re this,  this need taking care of to avoid infection! Wishing good luck to all of us.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2011 08:34AM abcd wrote: Thanks a lot to you all.......... Motheofpat..., Anna and Lago for your reply....... great help. Thanks.
Posts.Title: Taxotere advice please..... abcd abcd

Posts.Content: abcd wrote:  Hi,  After my three doses of FEC,  I am supposed to start with Taxotere ( three doses at three weeks interval ) from 16th of March.  I am scared as I heard this one can be pretty harsh.  I am looking for advice and suggestions regarding what should I do and what to expect?  BTW, I am from UK. Thanks. Dx 12/2010, IDC, Grade 3, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Taxotere advice please..... abcd abcd

Posts.Content: abcd wrote:  I had my last taxotere on 6th of April.  I had my chemotherapy started on 12th of Jan this year, Three FEC and two taxotere ( I refused the third  taxotere which was due on 27th of April).  Although I had scalp cooling with first 4 chemo, I did not bother taking scalp cooling during the 5th (my last) on 6th of April.  I am completely bald just now. I am nearly 65 and wonder if there is any chance I  will get my hair back! Those of you who had Taxotere and FEC, particularly of my age group, please share your hair regrowth experience.  How long after chemo discontinuation did you notice any hair coming back?  How long does it take to grow reasonable amount of hair?   can  I do anything to help the coming back? I am due lumpectomy with axillary node clearance on 19th of May.  Your experience would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.  Dx 12/2010, IDC, Grade 3, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: hair growth after chemotherapy abcd dorothym

Posts.Content: abcd wrote:  I am 63 and  diagnosed recently with grade 3 invasive ductal ca with 6 lymph node,  oestrogen receptor positive.   Oncologist appt coming week to discuss the plan of treatment.  Initiall before christmas, the BS did see me and suggested initial chemotherapy to shrink the tumour which is now found to be 20mm    He would like to remove the lump when it's shrunk.  My query to people at my situation........   Anyone ever felt.... what about not going through all these ordeal?   What I heard so far,  Chemo makes you feel so unwell,  leave you weak and then the hair loss ordeal and finally the inevitable ?mastectomy.   No one can avoid death, then why all these treatment torture?   Personally,  I always wanted quality of life which I had so far and still having.  Wonderful husband, two chidren and became first time grand parent 8 months ago to the most beautiful grandson. My feeling is,  if I now go for treatment, the quantity of life span may increase but I will lose that quality.  My husband and children ofcourse telling me that, it will be still painful at the end but what about pain relief and simply go off to sleep? Any one feels the way I feel?   I am probably thinking selfish when I am so much loved by my husband and my two children.... but would they NOT get tired of me if I drag too long?  To me that would be heartbreaking and indignified from my point of view but would welcome your views.  My husband is 69 and just 8months ago had angioplasty and stent put in and we both were determined to make it a success with follow up medicines and regular walking etc, and now I won't be walking with him with all these treatment and he would stop doing so as well.  So, I am a bit selfish in that regard and the idea of leaving him alone in old age is also selfish but life goes on,he will be okay one day and atleast I can go from this world with dignity!  SORRY,  I also developed cataract and the plan of sorting that out has to wait but forgive me, I CAN HARDLY READ what I am writing,so plenty mistakes....  ANYONE in favor of my thought process? Dx 12/2010, IDC, Grade 3, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Your views are welcome abcd libraylil

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 09:22PM abcd wrote:  Thanks for sharing your experiences.  I think the day before steroid would apply for the Taxotere part in my case.  May I also ask, how long have you people been diagnosed?   Has the life been same as before the treatment?  my family would probably feel relieved if I took the option of mastectomy first and then chemo but I chose the gamble to try to reduce the size of the tumour first by chemo, and then lumpectomy followed by radiotherapy ( all suggested by BS and approved by oncologist)..   Anyone in my situation?   2cm lump, grade 3, invasive ductal ca with 6 lymph nodes? What do you think is the survival rate? My daughter asked the oncologist but since I am not having biopsy from the surgery, they could not do the staging.  Are you all recently diagnosed or .....?  Do you have the same strength and stamina as you had prior to  this illness/treatment?
Posts.Title: Steroids and anti-emetic drugs prior to chemo abcd abcd

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 02:35PM abcd wrote: Hi,  Thanks to you all for your kind reply.   My mind is distracted today because of the oncology appt tomorrow for the treatment plan discussion, I suppose.  I also posted a new topic re CT OR MRI. So many questions......don't know what to ask and what not to!  I also do not understand what you all mean by HER,  I believe ER and PR means estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor but what is HER?   I am ER positive.  If anyone of you are the same, what chemo were you advised?  Did you have it intravenous or oral?   Did you need to stay as inpatient in the hospital overnight?  Did the chemo really shrink the tumour?  How frequent do you get chemo and at what interval and what is the total duration time?  Are you free in between to travel? Sorry to ask sooooooooooo many Q but please answer, you people know a lot and I am getting a lot of answers from you all,   A BIG THANK YOU.
Posts.Title: Your views are welcome abcd libraylil

Posts.Content: abcd wrote: Hi everyone. I am supposed to start my first chemo on 12th January.  I had a PICC line put in yesterday.  I asked them for a possible start of steroids and anti-emetics the day before chemo starts but I was told by the nursing team that they will give the steroids and anti-emetics just prior to the chemo drip, on the same day.  Please let me know of your experiences and what you think of this.  By the way, I am a UK resident. Dx 12/2010, IDC, Grade 3, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
